column1: This is a strong bill that will strengthen our military. It will help ensure the military can protect our nation in a world of challenges

column2: women in uniform need to respond to these crises and do the job the nation asks of them.

column1: But, the #NDAA is more than just answering these threats. It‚Äôs about helping us here at home, too.
The global turmoil of today highlights why the #NDAA bill before us is so important.
We remain a nation at war, with thousands of men and women in uniform still deployed to the Middle East and Afghanistan.
#NorthKorea is relentlessly pursuing long-range ballistic missiles capable of carrying nuclear warheads to our shores.
The number and complexity of threats we face today is unprecedented.
It was approved unanimously by the @SASCmajority committee: all 27 of our members voted for it.
Congress has passed this bipartisan legislation every year for the past 55 years. #NDAA

Corporal Matthew Alexander is truly a hero. He served with compassion &amp
column2: respect. It is an honor to tell his story. #NEheroes

column1: As Matthew‚Äôs father Mel put it, ‚ÄúMatthew had two passions, music and the military.‚Äù
To honor Matthew, his family established Matt‚Äôs Music Memorial. The charity helps children who love music but can‚Äôt afford an instrument
Corporal Alexander was laid to rest on May 18, 2007 in Nebraska. Over 1500 people attended to say their final goodbyes.
On May 6th Matthew spoke to his mother & Kara for the last time. A few days later an IED detonated near him, killing him instantly.
When Mathew returned to Baqubah, Iraq his unit encountered fierce fighting likened to the close-quarters combat of #Vietnam.
He returned home from combat and in February of 2007 married his childhood sweetheart, Kara, on Valentine‚Äôs Day.

Bill Bailey is a true Nebraska hero. I am honored to tell his story. #NEHeroes #ProudNebraskan
Bill was a wonderful husband, brother, son, father. He dedicated quite a bit of his life to helping other people. #NEHeroes
Specialist Bailey earned several military awards including the Purple Heart, Bronze Star, Iraqi Campaign Medal & Combat Action Badge. #Honor
More than one thousand people gathered in Bellevue to remember Bill. #NEHeroes
On May 25, 2007, during a security escort mission, Bill‚Äôs vehicle struck an improvised explosive device. Bill Bailey was killed. #NEHeroes
By 2007, the insurgency in Iraq had erupted to new levels of violence. Increased American forces sought to destroy the al Qaeda network.
In 2006, his unit was deployed and assigned to provide security escorts for truck convoys operating out of Balad Air Base in #Iraq.
That deep desire to serve the country continued to tug at him. In 2005, Bill re-enlisted in the @NENationalGuard #Courage
Bill‚Äôs protective nature made him a great father. It also made him a great firefighter. #NeHeroes
After 9/11, Bill felt the call to serve his country again. But, first things first. Bill and Dee married in 2004.
In December 2000, Bill met Dee. She was a bank teller at Wells Fargo; he drove an armored truck. They met through a service window.
Bill attended Bellevue East where the call to protect his country prompted him to enlist in the @NENationalGuard in 1995.

Let‚Äôs come together so we can look families in the eye and say: we heard you and we are taking action. #EqualPay #Bipartisan #Empowered
Let‚Äôs take advantage of this moment when we have common ground on a commonsense and straightforward legislation for #EqualPay #Bipartisan
Most importantly this bill is possible: 53 Republican and 5 Dem Senators supported a version of the #WorkplaceAdvancementAct last Congress.
Many congressional Democrats requested and even praised an Obama executive order with similar language to my proposal #EqualPay
Importantly for employers, the #WorkplaceAdvancementAct wouldn't impose new federal regulations or mandates
With this flexibility, women can better negotiate arrangements that make sense for them. #Flexibility
When employees, especially women, have more information, they can confidently pursue favorable work and wage arrangements #KnowledgeIsPower
A culture of silence and fear of retaliation can keep people in the dark about how their wages compare to others‚Äô #KnowledgeIsPower
The #WorkplaceAdvancementAct would empower women with info about wages so they can be informed advocates for themselves.

column1: RT @NENationalGuard: Thank you @SenatorFischer for honoring SGT Germaine Debro and the legacy of all Soldiers and Airmen in the Nebraska Na‚Ä¶
Watch my latest tribute to fallen #NEhero Sgt. Germaine Debro of Omaha: https://t.co/3ztsOhAnzj
He is a true Nebraska hero, and I am honored to tell his story. #SergeantGermaineDebro #NEHeroes
His military decorations include a Bronze Star and a Purple Heart. #Courage
Germaine Debro was promoted posthumously to the rank of sergeant. #NEheroes
On September 18, 2006, the Morning Star Baptist Church near downtown Omaha was filled with people paying a final tribute to Sgt. Debro.
Sergeant Josiah Warren, riding in the right seat, tried unsuccessfully to pull Germaine free. Sgt. Debro died on 9/4/06
Thirty miles outside Baghdad, Germaine‚Äôs Humvee struck an improvised explosive device.
On September 4, 2006, a 20-truck convoy headed out from a site 30 miles north of Baghdad.
Germaine‚Äôs unit was right in the thick of it. Enemy attacks were frequent. Tensions were high.
After a year of training, the First of the 167th Cavalry arrived in Iraq in early 2006. That‚Äôs when the Sunni-Shia civil war erupted.
In 2005, Germaine learned his unit, the First of the 167th Cavalry of the @NEnationalGuard, would deploy to Iraq.
Germaine deployed to Kuwait in 2001 and to Bosnia in 2002. #ProudNebraskan #NEheroes
In 1994, ‚ÄúG.I. Joe Maine‚Äù followed his calling and enlisted in the #Army and in 1997 joined the @NEnationalguard
Germaine Debro seemed destined for military service. At a young age, he picked up a nick name: ‚ÄúG.I. Joe Maine.‚Äù #NEheroes

Cpt Yllescas of Osceola, NE is an American hero. It was my honor to tell his story on the Senate floor #NEheroes https://t.co/7gXno8h8GZ
Captain Robert Yllescas embodied the pride of his state, served his country, and loved his family. #ProudNebraskan
Ultimately, Rob‚Äôs severe leg and head wounds were too much to overcome. Captain Robert Yllescas died on Dec. 1, 2008.
During Rob‚Äôs time at Bethesda Naval Medical Center, President George W. Bush visited him & personally awarded him the #PurpleHeart.
Rob was quickly evacuated out of Afghanistan, stabilized, and moved to the Bethesda Naval Medical Center.
On October 28, 2008, a remotely-controlled IED was detonated and seriously wounded Captain Yllescas.
Rob achieved the rank of #Captain and deployed to Afghanistan in 2008 and stationed at Camp Keating, known to many as dangerous territory.
Returning home to #Nebraska in 2006, Rob continued to excel in the military, later graduating from Army Ranger School. #RangersLeadTheWay
He deployed to Iraq in 2003 for a year & then returned for a 2nd deployment in 2005, when the fighting grew more intense.
In 2001, Rob received his commission as a Second Lieutenant in the @USArmy. #ArmyStrong
At @UNLincoln, he fell in love with his wife Dena and they were married on July 29, 2000.
Rob enrolled in the @NENationalGuard while in college at @UNLincoln with hopes of becoming a general one day. #NEHeroes

Sergeant Joshua Robinson is a hero, and I am honored to tell his story. #NEheroes
https://t.co/1SnR3eGdzN
Nebraskans will remember Joshua Robinson for what he embodied and what it means to be one of ‚Äúthe few and the proud ‚Äì a #Marine.‚Äù
Two months later, on August 7, 2011, Josh was out on patrol and shot twice by enemy combatants. He died shortly after.
He would later earn the Bronze Star for his actions that day. #ProudNebraskan #SemperFi
A few months later, on June 11, a fire fight broke out lasting six hours. During the attack, Josh rescued a wounded Marine. #Hero
After serving two tours in Iraq, he was deployed to Helmand Province, Afghanistan in March of 2011.
Josh‚Äôs fellow Marines say he was fearless. #SemperFi
By 2003, Josh had enlisted in the #Marine Corps. That year, he also met the love of his life, Rhonda Zaruba of Bennington, NE.
On 9/11, terrorist attacks on our homeland changed the world and instilled a deep sense of #duty and #patriotism for Josh.
Josh grew up on a farm near the small village of Oak, NE. He was born to be a #Marine.
Continuing my tribute to fallen #NEheroes today. I will honor the life of Sgt Joshua Robinson of Hastings. Watch: https://t.co/OZYnPFj0LM

column1: Marine Corporal Adrian Robles is a hero and I am honored to tell his story. #SemperFi #NebraskaHeroes
Adrian embodied the strength and determination that #Nebraskans are known for all over the world.
Adrian‚Äôs mother, Yolanda, recalls that his life‚Äôs passion was to serve his country. #Patriotism #SemperFi
Corporal Robles was killed instantly. His unit was scheduled to leave Afghanistan two months later. #NEHeroes #USMC
A few months later, on October 22, 2008, Adrian was on patrol when suddenly his vehicle was hit by an IED.
In the spring of 2008, Corporal Adrian Robles deployed to #Afghanistan as part of the 2nd Battalion, 1st Marine Division.
He graduated from Scottsbluff High School in May of 2005 &amp
column2: immediately enlisted in @USMC #Marines

column1: When her team arrived, the suspect opened fire and Kerrie was hit. Officer Orozco died shortly after.
On May 20, 2015, Officer Orozco was preparing to serve an arrest warrant as a member of the @OmahaPolice Metro Area Fugitive Task Force.
As an officer with the @OmahaPolice, Kerrie became active in the community she protected.
Officer Orozco had a natural instinct for leadership and service, which led her to join the police force in 2007.
Leadership and service were in Kerrie‚Äôs blood. Her aunt, Laurie McNeil, said Kerrie always wanted to be a cop. #SupportBlue

column1: Watch my full tribute to Master Sergeant Linda Tarango-Griess of Sutton, Nebraska on the #SenateFloor today. https://t.co/qc8iiaHllJ
I hope all Nebraskans remember her as an example of what it means to serve our nation with bravery, compassion, and joy. #NEheroes
Master Sergeant Linda Tarango-Griess was the first woman to lose her life in combat while serving in the @NENationalGuard.
Linda and another soldier were killed. She was only two weeks from returning to Nebraska. #NEHeroes
The convoy was attacked by al Qaeda insurgents, & Linda‚Äôs vehicle took a direct hit from an IED.
On July 11, 2004, Linda was driving in a convoy through a ‚Äúhigh-threat‚Äù area in Samarra, Iraq.
In February of 2004, Linda deployed with the 267th Ordinance Company, arriving at Camp Speicher near Tikrit, Iraq.
Through the @NationalGuard, Linda discovered her passion for being a soldier in the U.S. military.
Linda‚Äôs willingness to serve as a role model and mentor for others came as no surprise to those who knew her.
Headed to the #SenateFloor to honor the life of Master Sergeant Linda Tarango-Griess of Sutton, NE. #NEHeroes https://t.co/3tNtRIdHIv

Jake‚Äôs memory lives on in the hearts and minds of the state he served. Nebraskans are forever indebted to his sacrifice. 11/12

Jake and 3 other soldiers were taken hostage, stripped of their identification, and shot as the militants fled the scene. 6/12
Shortly after he arrived, on January 20, 2007, enemy militants disguised as friendly soldiers, entered Karbala and attacked. 5/12
Lieutenant Fritz had a natural instinct to step up and take charge. He felt an obligation and commitment to the mission. 4/12
In 2006, Jake was deployed to Iraq as a Lieutenant with the 2nd Battalion 3/12

Sgt  Hansen is a hero & I‚Äôm honored to tell his story, lest we forget his life & the freedom he fought to defend #NEheroes 11/11
Our nation, and all Nebraskans, are forever indebted to Jeff‚Äôs service and sacrifice 10/11
For his service, Jeff was awarded the Iraqi Campaign Medal, the Global War on Terrorism Service Medal & Armed Forces Reserve Medal 9/11
Jeff was quickly flown to Germany for emergency care. He passed away a few days later with Jenny at his side. 8/11
Jeff pushed the other soldiers out of the vehicle, all of whom survived the crash #NEheroes 7/11
Out of nowhere, Jeff‚Äôs Humvee hit a sinkhole and flipped, landing upside down in a canal 6/11
Jeff‚Äôs unit arrived in Iraq just before the al-Askari mosque bombing in 2006 5/11
He met his wife Jenny at a football game at @UNKearney 4/11
In civilian life Jeff became a #Kearney police officer, & later joined the @DeptVetAffairs Police Force in Grand Island 3/11
Jeff exhibited outstanding leadership as a member of Troop A in the 1-167th Cavalry of the @NENationalGuard 2/11
Jeff grew up with the heart of a soldier & over the years, the urge to serve his country tugged at him #NEheroes 1/11

I look forward to pursuing shared solutions worthy of our people in the days and weeks to come.
That‚Äôs because of my unwavering faith in the fundamental goodness, tenacity, and creativity of the American people.
Yet, I believe that our very best days as a nation are ahead.
or grandparents concerned about the future we will leave our grandchildren, there is no shortage of anxiety.
Whether it‚Äôs hardworking parents trying to make ends meet
I know many families across our state and across our nation are worried.
and creating flexible options for working families remain at the forefront of my priorities.
Building a stronger Nebraska, giving Americans more opportunities and more certainty‚Ä¶
There is more work to do.
to funding our military and passing policies to help prevent suicide among our veterans, we acted on the will of the American people.
From enacting a multi-year highway bill and reforming our education system...
Last year, we were able to make progress on many big issues.
By working together, we can deliver meaningful results and a brighter future for the American people.
To provide real and lasting solutions, we need a positive vision to unite behind and move forward.
Our nation faces many challenges, from escalating dangers abroad to limited economic opportunities here at home. #SOTU
